speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we have time for one more caller.  Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: We have Ed on line three.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Ed, I'm listening. [_no answer_] Ed? [_no answer_] Ed? Well, we seem to have lost Ed.  Let's take another caller. On line four we have.... Roz?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz?

speaker: Frasier
text: We have....

speaker: Frasier
text: Eye...

speaker: Frasier
text: Lean. [_then:_] Oh, Eileen.  Hello Eileen, I'm listening.

speaker: Eileen
text: [_v.o:_] Dr. Crane, I've been very happily married for twenty years and I wouldn't dream of cheating, but lately when we're making love I find myself fantasizing about people... other than my husband.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's perfectly normal.  It's quite normal to spice up one's love life by imagining a tryst with, oh, a sports figure or a movie star or...

speaker: Eileen
text: Or a radio psychiatrist?

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Eileen
text: It's your voice, Dr. Crane.  You must have the most sensuous voice on earth.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_putting on a sensuous voice:_] Oh, I don't know, Eileen.

speaker: Eileen
text: I've never seen your picture.  Would you mind describing yourself?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well I don't really think that's appropriate...

speaker: Roz
text: I'll do it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I don't think...

speaker: Roz
text: He's about six-one, with a granite jaw and the broad shoulders of a marine.  He's been wearing his hair short lately but that only accentuates his cobalt blue eyes, his chiseled cheekbones and his full, provocative lips.

speaker: Eileen
text: Wow!  Thanks Roz, and thank you, Dr. Crane.  I'll be thinking of you tonight - with any luck, twice! [_hangs up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, this is Dr. Frasier Crane feeling a little red in his chiseled cheeks.  Till tomorrow then, this is KACL 780 AM. [_signs off air_] _As Frasier presses a button Roz enters his booth and goes to the tape deck._

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, that was quite a flattering description.  You know, just out of curiosity: were you just helping that lady with her fantasy or do you really see me that way?

speaker: Roz
text: [_freezes, then in a haunted voice:_] You really don't know, do you? [_turns around_] Frasier, I am so attracted to you, I always have been. [_starts to get closer to him_] Your looks, your voice...

speaker: Roz
text: You don't know how many times I've wanted to strip naked and hurl myself at that glass partition like a bug on a windshield.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you through?

speaker: Roz
text: [_smacks his head_] Well, ask a stupid question! _She gets off of him and goes back to the tape deck as Frasier sorts his briefcase out._

speaker: Frasier
text: All right Roz, I will see you tomorrow.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, aren't you going to the staff meeting?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, just tell them that my aunt died.  I'm off to her lawyer's now, she put me in charge of her memorial.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I'm so sorry.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, don't be, she was a dreadful old harpy.  Life around her was miserable.

speaker: Roz
text: That should look nice on her headstone.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I don't mean any disrespect but you know, the entire time I knew her she never said anything to me that wasn't scornful, derisive or contemptuous.

speaker: Roz
text: So how come she made you in charge of her memorial?

speaker: Frasier
text: I was her favourite! _FADE OUT  Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment. Daphne is cutting Martin's hair at the dinner table whilst he reads the paper.  Niles and Frasier enter with bags and they ad-lib greetings.  Frasier notices Eddie rolling on the couch._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I thought we had an agreement: Eddie doesn't roll around on the sofa and I don't throw him in front of a bus!

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, hello Dr. Crane.  Will you be joining us for dinner?

speaker: Niles
text: If it's not too much trouble.  It's Maris's night to host her book club and they are more comfortable not having a man there.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, apparently Niles makes the ladies self-conscious.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I sat in on the last discussion and Mrs. Esterbrook- Kindred developed a facial tic every time she had to say the word "Balzac."

speaker: Martin
text: So how did it go with Aunt Louise's lawyer?  Did you get the old bat's affairs straightened out?

speaker: Niles
text: Ask her yourself. _Niles places her urn on the table.  This causes Eddie to run off down the corridor to Martin's room._

speaker: Frasier
text: Apparently, it was Aunt Louise's wish that Niles dispose of her ashes.

speaker: Niles
text: Now the pressure's on me to find the perfect place for her to rest for eternity.  I haven't the faintest idea what to do with her.

speaker: Martin
text: Why don't you just flush her down the toilet?

speaker: Daphne
text: Mr. Crane, you can't do that!

speaker: Martin
text: Why not?  She loved the water.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, oh, that's it: the beach.  Oh, no, no, she hated seagulls. And vice-versa. [_then:_] Oh, oh, oh... no! [_then:_] It doesn't matter where I pick, you know it's not going to be good enough.  Whatever I did she always found fault.  Remember when I used to mow her lawn?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, what about the Christmas tree I bought her?

speaker: Niles
text: The ashtray I made at camp?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_imitating her:_] "Is that the best you can do?  It wobbles!"

speaker: Niles
text: [_to urn:_] I wish I had that ashtray now!

speaker: Martin
text: So when's the memorial service?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's two weeks after tomorrow.  Lucky lucky me, her last request was that I deliver the eulogy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh come on now, you can handle it.  You just stand up there and say a few nice things.

speaker: Frasier
text: There aren't any!

speaker: Daphne
text: Then just make them up.  Everyone lies a little in eulogies.

speaker: Frasier
text: No Daphne, I refuse to invent virtues the woman didn't have. I'll just have to find something good I can honestly say about her.

speaker: Martin
text: [_stands:_] Good luck!  She was nothing but a crabby, tight- fisted old pain.  All she ever did was sit around that house day after day watching TV.  She kept that same old cruddy furniture all her life. _Martin sits down in his old chair in front of the box prompting Niles and Frasier to give a stare at each other._

speaker: Martin
text: What?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, remember how she always used to complain about the winters?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh yeah, every year she was going to take a trip to the South Pacific.  It was her big dream.  But would she spend the money?  Nooooo.  She just sat around whining all the time about how she'd like to be in a warmer climate.

speaker: Frasier
text: My guess is she finally made it.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_hinting:_] I think it would be terribly bad to go through life having a secret dream and never fulfilling it.  You'd never do anything silly like that, would you Mr. Crane?

speaker: Martin
text: What're you talking about?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I don't know.  Perhaps a little something involving a certain shoebox you keep hidden.

speaker: Frasier
text: Shoebox?

speaker: Martin
text: Forget it, it's not important.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh fine, if you don't want to talk about it, don't talk about it.  It's only something you've given over thirty years of your life to.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, I didn't tell you that so you can go around blabbing it to everyone.

speaker: Frasier
text: Tell us, dad, what's in the shoe box?

speaker: Martin
text: Nothing, all right?

speaker: Martin
text: It's just some songs I wrote... for Frank Sinatra.

speaker: Daphne
text: And he keeps them in his shoebox.

speaker: Martin
text: I think your work here is done.

speaker: Martin
text: Your mother and I used to listen to Sinatra all the time. I know most of his songs by heart.  I guess I got it into my head one day that I'd try to write a song myself.  I'd be at the station house or on a stakeout, I'd get an idea and pretty soon I had a shoebox full.  I used to imagine your mother and I seeing Frank in the stands in Vegas and he'd open the show with one of my songs.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh gee, dad, why did you never tell us about this?

speaker: Martin
text: Because it is stupid.  They were no good...

speaker: Niles
text: Oh...

speaker: Martin
text: And don't bother to ask, I'm not letting you see 'em.

speaker: Daphne
text: Here they are. Just like I told you, in his shoebox.

speaker: Niles
text: [_reads:_] "You are the song my soul would sing."

speaker: Frasier
text: Very poetic.

speaker: Niles
text: [_reads:_] "You make my heart go ring-a ding-ding."

speaker: Martin
text: That was during Frank's ring-a-ding period.

speaker: Frasier
text: Lord, this shoebox is full of them. [_reads:_] "I didn't mean to hurt her, she made me lose my mind".

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, lemme see that! [_reads then:_] No, that's just some confession I took from a guy.  The lyrics are on the back. Anyway, I never finished them.  They were never any good. [_picks one up_] Well, except this.  I gotta admit this has got "Frank Sinatra" written all over it.

speaker: Niles
text: [_reads:_] "She's such a groovy lady."

speaker: Martin
text: It's still got that nice contemporary sound.

speaker: Daphne
text: So, why don't you send it to old Blue Eyes?

speaker: Martin
text: No, they're just words scribbled on a piece of paper.  The tune's in my head, I don't know how to write it down.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Niles and I do.  You've got the tune in your head, why don't you let us write it down for you?  _They begin arguing over this and Martin decides it's a bad idea. So Daphne is tactical._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, you're wasting your breath trying to convince him to do something.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, come on. [_he refuses:_] Yeah, you're probably right. You just sit there night after night watching TV until the time finally comes when we collect your ashes and scatter them over that chair - where they'll probably go unnoticed.

speaker: Martin
text: [_realising:_] All right, okay.  _Niles and Frasier are overjoyed and run to the piano.  Niles sits down claiming he'll be sitting at the piano, however Frasier isn't too happy about this.  Martin goes up near to the piano and they begin._

speaker: Martin
text: Okay, so boys, the way I'm hearing the intro, it goes something like this.  _Martin shouts a weird noise mixed with bwobbety-bwas, scobba-doobas, and finishing an unearthly noise sounding like "bwaaaaaa!"_

speaker: Niles
text: Of course, it is your piano.  _Niles stands up, however Frasier pushes him back into his seat realising that he ended up with the best job after all.  End Of Act One.  Act Two.  Scene One - Frasier's Apartment - Night.  Niles is at the piano.  Frasier is stood up behind him and Martin is sat on a high chair by the piano.  It's late at night, and all three men are in their undershirts.  Niles is playing the conclusion to the song, and Martin is happily snapping his fingers in time to it._

speaker: Martin
text: No, no, it goes: Groovy lady of mine, ba-ba-ba-bap-bam-ba-a- aaa-a-a-a!

speaker: Niles
text: Like: [_plays something along those lines_]

speaker: Martin
text: No, no, come on, this is the big finish.  Ba-ba-bap-bam-ba-a- aaa-a-a-a!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, dad, in Niles's defense, after four hours your "ba-bap- ba-ba-a-a-a's sound a lot like your "scoopety, boop, bop, bam!"  Right, Niles, let's just try it again.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah!  That's it.

speaker: Niles
text: All right?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  Let's hear the chorus one last time.

speaker: Frasier
text: She's such a groovy lady, She makes my heart go heidi-hiedi, She is the chick I spend my nights dreaming off...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_stops:_] Niles. [_Niles stops_] Dad, I don't mean to criticise. You know that "heidi-hiedi?"  It sounds like Cab Calloway sung backwards.

speaker: Martin
text: You got any better suggestions?

speaker: Niles
text: Er, yes, yes: "She's like a wood, all cool and shady!"

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no: "She makes the bravest cat go 'fraidy!"

speaker: Daphne
text: I've got it: "She could have slept with Warren Beatty!"

speaker: Frasier
text: [_patronising:_] Very nice Daphne, no.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I'm sticking with my one, keep singing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Her lips are red as ruby, She makes my heart go scooby dooby, She is the broad who makes me coo-coo in the heart.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I don't mean to quibble but it seems like her heart is always going heidi-hiedi, ringy-dingy, or scooby dooby.

speaker: Martin
text: Look, I don't need another critic.

speaker: Niles
text: Fine, perhaps a cardiologist?

speaker: Martin
text: In all due respect, I think I'm a little more tuned in to what Frank likes and this is pretty close to perfect the way it is.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well?

speaker: Martin
text: How about that!  Thirty years and I've finally finished it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Never too late.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, first thing tomorrow, I'm mailing it to Frank's people. A little help from Lady Luck, maybe they'll kick it upstairs to the chairman himself. [_starts singing:_] "She's such a groovy lady, [_throws sweater over his shoulder:_] She makes my heart go heidi-hiedi..." [_walks off_]  _The Crane brothers and Daphne look on with an air of pride as the scene FADES OUT.  Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment. Two weeks later it is the morning of Aunt Lousie's funeral.  Frasier is still writing his eulogy on paper.  However, he takes the paper, rips it up and starts again.  A photo album is also laid out on the table.  Martin enters._

speaker: Martin
text: Oh Jeez!  The service is in an hour.  Aren't you finished with that eulogy yet?

speaker: Frasier
text: I can't even come up with a first line.  I got this old photo album, probably one of her pictures might inspire me.

speaker: Martin
text: How about this: "We all loved Aunt Louise, even if the camera didn't!" [_laughs with Frasier_]

speaker: Daphne
text: [_enters with a tissue - her voice sounds like she has a cold:_] Dr. Crane, you've been agonising over this for two weeks. Perhaps it's time to start bending the truth a little.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I refuse to lie.

speaker: Martin
text: Why?

speaker: Daphne
text: I find it hard to believe there isn't one nice story you can tell about her.  Maybe a cute little saying she used?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm not sure that, "Stop crying, or I'll give you something to cry about" would qualify.

speaker: Daphne
text: Where are you off to?

speaker: Martin
text: Just going to go check the mail.

speaker: Daphne
text: I wish they'd just give him an answer about that song.  He must have made a hundred trips to the mailbox during the past two weeks. [_sneezes_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, bless you, Daphne.  Are you sure you're up to coming to the memorial?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, it's just a little cold. [_blows nose_] Besides, in my family, when there was a funeral everybody went.  I remember when Grammy Moon passed on.  My brothers had been off on a three-day bender.  They couldn't even stand on their own - pissed as newts!  But they crawled to that chapel on their hands and knees.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very commendable.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, well, they had an obligation.  They were the pallbearers.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh dear Lord, Niles, don't tell me you haven't disposed of those ashes yet.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I have taken them to a dozen locations.  Fossy glade, a babbling brook, a moonlit pond.  None of them felt right, what am I going to do?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, winter's coming.  The sidewalks are always slippery. I'm having the same problem with the eulogy!

speaker: Niles
text: [_sees album_] Oh, remember when this photo was taken - the day Aunt Lousie took me to Wilson's Meadow to fly a kite? It cost her 35 cents and when it got stuck in a tree she made me climb up after it.  I fell out, broke my collarbone in two places.  I think that's the only time I saw her laugh. [_inspired_] Frasier!  I think she might be happy there!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I think you might be right.

speaker: Niles
text: And even if she's not, let's still do it.

speaker: Daphne
text: Any news about your song?

speaker: Martin
text: Nah.  Listen, we better get started.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.  Perhaps I'll have some inspiration on the way over in the car.

speaker: Niles
text: And Wilson's Meadow is on the way.  We can stop and scatter the ashes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, this sounds like a family affair.  Maybe I'll take my car and meet you there.

speaker: Martin
text: All right, let's go.

speaker: Niles
text: Wilson's Meadow is the perfect place.  Aunt Louise, you've tormented me for two weeks and finally I've shown you I can do something right.  _Martin, Frasier and Niles exit the front door.  After a pause Niles enters again to pick up the urn of ashes he left behind._

speaker: Niles
text: [_to urn:_] Oh, shut up!  _Niles exits with urn.  FADE TO:  Scene Three - Wilson's Meadow. The three pull up in the car - Frasier driving, Niles in the passenger seat and Martin in the back._

speaker: Niles
text: Here, here, yes, yes.  Perfect. [_about urn:_] There's something rattling in here.  Like some great grisly morata. _Niles gets out.  Throughout the following conversation between Martin and Frasier we see Niles trying to get the urn open unsuccessfully. He even hits it against a tree and jumps on it._

speaker: Frasier
text: What am I going to say at this memorial?

speaker: Martin
text: Don't ask me.

speaker: Frasier
text: You write lyrics, don't ya?

speaker: Martin
text: Right!  Tell that to Sinatra!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dad, it's a good sing.  I even caught myself singing it in the shower this morning.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just because you haven't heard anything yet doesn't mean... you have heard something?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah. [_takes out letter:_] This morning they rejected it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm sorry, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it's okay.  Sinatra must gets thousands of songs sent to him.  What did I expect?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, at least you gave it your best shot.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I guess.  I mean, sure it would have been nice to hear it sung, but hey, I finished it, finally!  Yeah, I walked down that highway, and climbed that mountain, and reached for the stars. [_realising lyric-like sentence_] Oh sure, now I get hot!

speaker: Niles
text: I can't open the damn urn!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gets out:_] Oh, you are so helpless!  For Pete's sake, give it to me, give it to me.  _Frasier yanks the lip open.  However, the ashes gust out and cover Niles and Frasier.  They try to dust themselves clean.  FADE TO:  Scene Four - Church. It's the memorial service.  Daphne is sat down on the front row. Martin and Niles join her._

speaker: Martin
text: It looks like Louise's whole rest home showed up.  It must be "Liver & Onions Day" in the cafeteria.

speaker: Daphne
text: Apparently when they heard it was Frasier Crane from the radio speaking, the whole rest home turned out.  Can't wait to hear what he has to say.

speaker: Niles
text: Neither can he: He's huddled in the rectory still working on his first sentence.

speaker: Daphne
text: How did the scattering go?  Were there any problems?

speaker: Niles
text: No, nothing important.  _Niles takes off his shoe and empties some ashes out onto the floor. The service begins._

speaker: Minister
text: Dear friends, thank you all for coming today.  I know how very deeply your friendship was treasured by Louise.  We are privileged to have with us her favourite nephew, one of Seattle's most eloquent speakers, Dr. Frasier Crane.  Dr. Crane has spent the last fortnight reflecting on what Louise meant to him.  Dr. Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, well, well.  What can I say about Aunt Louise?  What can I say?  Louise... touched us all. [_dusts his clothes:_] In fact, she touches us still. [_dusts again_] Aunt Louise... loved to teach us all lessons.  You know, it's hard to picture her without hearing her saying, "I'm going to teach you a lesson." What particularly comes to mind, by the very way she lived her own life: she taught us how important it is to pursue our dreams. [_Martin looks up_] Whether we succeed or fail, what really matters is that we tried.  And now as we say goodbye to Louise, a phrase comes to mind.  It was coined by my very own father... "She's Such A Groovy Lady."

speaker: Frasier
text: I said, "She's Such A Groovy Lady."

speaker: Choir
text: Oh, that groovy lady, Oh, that groovy lady...

speaker: Choir
text: She's such a groovy lady, She makes my heart go heidi-hiedi, She is the chick I spend my nights dreaming of.  Her lips are red as ruby, She makes my heart go scooby dooby, She makes me wanna shout "Hey Vagers, above!"  She's got the whole world swinging, She makes my heart start ringing-dinging,  That hubba hubba groovy lady of mine, Of mine, of mine,  That hubba hubba groovy lady of mine, Oh yeah, Oh yeah...

speaker: Base
text: Yeah!

speaker: Choir
text: Yeah!  _Niles, Daphne and Martin have been dancing in their seats and clap along with the congregation and the studio audience.  End Of Act Two._
